I was told by many people that this was one of the best movies ever, but after finally seeing it, i feel a little bit stupider than when i started. I think I may have actually lost brain cells by watching this trash. A plot less movie centered around a total loser. I couldn't seem to follow any coherent sense of a story, and with an ending that resolves nothing, I was left pondering what actually happened in the last 2 hours that made any sense. To top it off, the humor was crude, tasteless, and just plain unfunny. I didn't laugh even once for a movie deemed a "comedy". Stay as far away as possible all of you!Such a sad waste of two hours of my life I can never get back. . .

"The Big Lebowski" was a wonderful film about life's struggles through the eyes of a "cool" slacker. The plot steers us through a network of rich people problems to the harsh reality of life and death. Jeff Bridges plays the role of "The Dude" absolutely perfectly. The Dude gets entangled in a twisted kidnap/ransom plot that introduces a wide variety of personalities. Walter Sobchak (John Goodman) adds energy to the conflict with his crazy rash behavior. Walter's nutty actions help to reinforce The Dude as the position of reason. his's antics drive the ransom scenes and help insert excitement into a meaningless sequence. Walter and The Dude escalate the situation by not completely following the kidnapper's directions. The situation snowballs as the truth is slowly revealed. Donny (Steve Buscemi) does little to influence the plot and is included mainly as comic relief for the first part of the movie. His conversations seem distance and irrelevant, but in the end, his character helps to ground the story and remind of us what really matters in this world. Maude Lebowski (Julianne Moore) introduces herself to the situation and gives us some insight about the kidnapping. Maude is used in this film to convey information about her father, The Big Lebowski, played by David Huddleston. Although her role is very helpful, her demeanor and snooty personality distracts and pulls attention from the flow of the theme. As I watched this great film, I felt this sequence could have been routed a bit differently to help the plot instead of hinder it. The German's added a good amount of comic relief as their characters helped to tie the whole kidnapping ploy together. The Nihilist's added another dimension to this theme that was meant to make light of the whole abduction. This film has a lot in common with the movie "Raising Arizona". Both films revolve around attempts to extort the rich for money, while outlasting crazy and funny events. Both films become grounded in the end by life and death. The lighting in the ransom delivery sequence was extremely appropriate and seemed to mimic the typical suspenseful car ride. The music and even the color of Walter's glasses help to add to the adventurous feeling we were intended to experience in this scene. The shot angles during the bowling scenes definitely helped the music to calm our emotions from the conflicts of the kidnapping and peacefully install us back into the mind of The Dude. I absolutely loved this movie and would recommend it to anyone with an open mind. This crazy adventure has a little bit of everything exciting, sex drugs and rock and roll, but also remains grounded, expressing the trials of life and death.

I honestly don't understand how this movie is so popular. I wanted to watch it to see what all the fuss was about, and I barely made it through an hour of the movie. I laughed a grand total of once in the entire time, and that was within the first five minutes. It's slow, stupid, and has little to no value.(POSSIBLE SPOILER?) The only "redeeming" scene is apparently a fantasy scene involving Julianne Moore's character and bowling, but I couldn't stomach watching any more of the movie for the sole purpose of seeing this scene. It was a waste of my time and money. I highly recommend NOT watching this movie. It's really not that big a loss, even if it is one of IMDb's top 250 movies. It's not worth the bother.

Review title: Your revolution is over Mr. Lebowski!
Review_body: I've lost count of how many times I've seen this film and each time it seems to get better and better. Yet, the first time I saw this film I didn't think it was a great movie since I didn't realize the true greatness of it (in fact, I think no one did). This is because the movie is not about the plot or about the message. This movie is great because of its characters, dialogue and aesthetics, things that are most appreciated with successive viewings. It's the little details that will make this your favourite comedy of all time.Jeff Bridges, John Goodman and Steve Buscemi are outstanding as the three bowling buddies and excellently supported by Philip Seymour Hoffman and Julianne Moore. In fact I think most would agree that Jeff Bridges and especially John Goodman gave award-winning performances. The dialogue is truly amazing. I mean how many movies are bestowed with so many memorable lines as this one? It is also truly unique. For a good-hearted and laid-back sort of film, to contain that many and different subtle references to cultural idiosyncrasies really says something. Finally, and I think this is what gives the movie defining cult status, it's the aesthetics. You can tell the effort made by directors and actors alike in carefully constructing each character. Each character has been embedded with a particular style and ethos which explain their way of going about things. Each character is both cause and effect of different generational prototypes mingling with each other in that psychedelic fauna that is The Big Lebowski.

Review title: The Dude finds himself in over his head after a millionaire with the same name hires him to do a job for him.
Review_body: The Big Lebowski centers around "The Dude" wonderfully played by Jeff Bridges, who finds himself (and his rug) on the wrong end of a mistaken Identity caper. He is offered a job from another "Lebowski" (a millionaire played by David Huddlestone) to be a courier for the millionaire Lebowski and enlists his two friends Donny (Steve Buscemi) and Walter (John Goodman) a former Viet Nam veteran for help. After a series of unfortunate events, The Dude and his friends find themselves in over their heads, and The Dude may be on the line for much more than he ever asked for. The themes of this film seems to center around misinformation, being in the wrong place at the wrong time, and manipulation. Everything about the film seems like it was devised by The Big Lebowski, or is the result of misinformation and being at the wrong place at the wrong time. The plan by The Big Lebowski seems to have already at least have been thought of, if not already in motion by the time The Dude shows up at his mansion demanding compensation for the rug that was urinated on by the thugs trying to collect a debt from The Big Lebowski. The Dude is then coerced into a plan that has him running dangerous errands and meeting all kinds of sketchy characters that he probably would never have run into if it weren't for the unfortunate timing and bad luck of this mistaken identify case.The Coen brothers do a masterful job of mixed witty and hilarious dialogue with suspense and action. All of their films, this one included, feel like a work of art as opposed to a big budget comedy romp. The editing, lighting, and soundtrack really enhance and contribute on their own right to making this film as great as it is. The soundtrack perfectly balances between The Dudes hazy lifestyle to opera like signing while a party-goer at Jacky Treehorn's home is thrown into the air in slow-motion on a trampoline. The theme of this film has parallels to other films by the Coen brothers, for example in the film No Country For Old Men, the lead character Llewelyn Moss (Josh Brolin) stumbles upon a crime scene one night while out hunting. Being at the wrong place at the wrong time leads Llewelyn down a dark path and finds himself running for his life throughout the film. The Big Lebowski deserves to be talked about as one of the best Coen brothers films to date. It has a complex and twisting plot that allows for multiple viewings without boredom, an all star cast who each masterful carve out their characters in a humorous yet compelling style, and the direction and writing from the Coen's is top notch and will have audiences quoting The Dude for many years ahead.

Review title: the plane has crashed into the side of the mountain
Review_body: The Big Lebowski is an epic film that has "strikes and gutter-balls...ups and downs." The cast is spectacular. There are many stars that appear in this film. Jeff Bridges does a great job playing the wonderfully lazy: The Dude. John Goodman is very funny as high tempered Vietnam vet. And Steve Buscemi's character, Donny, is very funny as the innocent victim of Goodman's temper. I can not picture any other actors playing these characters, or the other characters for that matter. The Big Lebowski has an excellent plot, something that most comedies seem to lack. This is a must see movie that will have you repeating some quotes from the film to your friends on a regular basis. This is one of the funniest films of all time. THE DUDE ABIDES...

Trust me, I am a very open minded film viewer and have enjoyed a vast variety of movies. This film however was a complete waste of time.I got what was trying to be achieved with the movie but it just didn't get any where near where it was supposed to.Sorry folks, a terrible movie that had good intentions but bad guidance!It seems this was a movie that Tarantino would have got a few ideas from but then made a so much more enjoyable film. I was just sitting watching it getting more bored and tired by the minute.This film has a serious 'false' rating.

When "The Big Lebowski" was released in 1998, it wasn't a big hit. I was born in '98. Since then the Movie has generated itself to a cult classic and for some good reasons. The Story is a typical Coen Brother story but still stay's original. The cast did tremendous job representing the characters written for the screen. Jeff Bridges rubbing his eyes before The Dude was high in some scenes or John Goodmans nailing performance as a sort of John Milius look-a-like. The iconic outfits that you can buy on Amazon for Halloween.And since I saw the movie for the first time, I always after watching it get the need to mix myself a White Russian and listen to Kenny Rogers' Just Dropped In. And you know why? Because it's a cult classic.
A series of mundane events in the lives of some consistently lame guys. Extremely overrated.Move on, you won't miss anything.

The main story of this film opens up with Jeff "The Dude" Lebowski (Jeff Bridges) having his rug urinated on. The cause of this unfortunate event was a mix-up by the thugs, as "The Dude" Jeff Lebowski shares a name with a millionaire Jeff Lebowski (David Huddleston). This prompts The Dude to go over to The Big Lebowski and demand compensation for the rug. This leads to The Big Lebowski having The Dude be his courier to deliver ransom money when his wife gets kidnapped. The ransom drop goes awry when Walter (John Goodman) gets involved, which lead to the whole somewhat convoluted chain of events in the rest of the film.One of the major themes of the film is The Dude pacifism. What makes the film interesting is that while he is a pacifist, he spends the majority of the film being angry. However, you can always see his laid-back peaceful personality underneath everything. When the thugs broke into his apartment in the beginning of the movie, one of them water boarded him in his own toilet. However, when he talks about it with Walter the next day, he does not even mention being water boarded. He's just upset about the loss of his rug. We also see this later in the film, when his second rug is stolen. When he meets Maude (Julianne Moore), who was the person who stole the rug, they have a long conversation, with the rug being mentioned several times. At the end of the conversation, Maude apologizes for having him punched in the jaw. He replies, "Oh, that's fine. That doesn't even..." When she insists he see the doctor, he says, "That's thoughtful but..." He doesn't care about being beaten, he just wants a rug.The editing and camera angles in the film are simple and direct. With few exceptions, there are no real fancy editing effects or transitions. The only time there are any fancy effects in the film are in dream sequences. Additionally, the colors of the film, especially The Dude's clothes, are simple and muted. This represents The Dude's simple, laid-back attitude on life.Overall, The Big Lebowski is a great film. The characters in the movie all have their own personality and backstory, and that makes the whole film feel alive. The dialog is engaging, especially with everyone's personality being in contrast with The Dude's. After seeing it for the first time, this is already one of my favorite films.

To me this movies is about a man who is complete, he is happy: has a hobby that is a love of his life, has friends that love his hobby as well, and has enough money for gas, and oh, did I mention a rug that really ties the room together. But to me this movie is about all of that and yet none of that. Its a movie about being happy with who you are and not letting others tell you how to be happy. During the first run of this film I say it 50+ times in the the theater, during lunch I would go see 15-30 minutes of it, after work I would see it twice. And this was the time period in cinema movies would stay in the theater for months, sometimes almost a year. So I have plenty of chances to see it. It was an escape for me wanting stuff, a reminder that poverty as well as wealth is only as good as how you choose to feel about it.

I love most to all Coen movies but anyone who believes this is not their best work is just wrong. I realize that is just like my opinion man but I defy you to find a more quotable movie, with more entertaining characters anywhere. Mark it an 8, or better, or you are just over the line! I am down with Fargo, which seems to be the other popular fan favorite for the Coens, but it is still 4th best at best. Big Lebowski is clear cut #1 Hudsucker Proxy is arguable #2 3rd could be: Raising Arizona, Blood Simple, or Miller's Crossing 4th: Fargo comes in ahead of O' Brother and Intolerbale Cruelty...barely. Grab some caucasians, sit back, and reevaluate the Dude, for your own good.

I stumbled across this film a few times on different recommendations and was never really interested in the idea of it. But once I sat down and actually watched it, I was laughing almost through out the whole film. Everything just seems to go go wrong for the dude and its very funny to watch. All he wanted was a new rug.

Review title: funny movie about what could happen in a case of mistaken identity
Review_body: one of the most underrated comedies of all time. this movie is as funny as any other comedy and maybe even funnier. Jeff bridges is great as well as john Goodman. the story line is hysterical. this is one of those movies you need to see twice to really appreciate it. if you need a good laugh the big lebowski is the remedy to cure your woes. a must see...twice!

Review title: A stoned bum is thrown into a strange kidnapping case and he is tasked with being a key component in getting back the kidnapped.
Review_body: The Big Lebowski is really it's own kind of film. It's characters are all strange but yet seem to fit in perfectly. There seems to be no line drawn in the sand to limit The Big Lebowski's creativity and bizarreness. Its main character alone has been such a draw that he has been the source of a new religion; Dudeism. The directors of The Big Lebowski, the Coen Brothers, are known for their unique filmography and outside-the-box thinking, but The Big Lebowski is certainly one of the movies that granted them that title.We begin our journey from the outside, starting with The Stranger. An old cowboy who already knows The Dude himself (Jeff Bridges). The Stranger acts as a character, narrator and audience member all at the same time. He talks tall tales about The Dude, and we are promptly dropped into his world. The Dude roams around L.A. and bowls in his free time, always scavenging for his next White Russian and couch to kick back on. The Dude walks back home one day only to find two henchmen waiting for him. One throws The Dude's head in his own gross toilet and the other unzips his pants and pees on his rug. It really tied the room together. One henchmen goes on to explain that the two are there to extort money from The Dude, calling him "Mr Lebowski." Only, they've got the wrong Lebowski. The two leave in an aggressive embarrassment and The Dude is left on his bathroom floor with a toilet-water-soaked head and sunglasses on.The Dude does some digging and eventually finds the real Mr. Lebowski in an attempt to get some money to replace his rug. The two meet in Mr. Lebowski's illustrious house, and The Dude leaves without any money but having tricked Mr. Lebowski's personal assistant, Brandt, into stealing a rug for him. As The Dude leaves he winds up chatting up Mr. Lebowski's trophy wife, Bunnie, as well.The Dude is a toker for sure. Always kicking back and lighting some J's, he proves himself to be The Dude time and time again. The Dude's casual mindset pairs well with his habit of smoking weed and in a good amount of scenes he is. However it's almost like he goes unchanged. There isn't a sober dude and there isn't a high Dude he just is, The Dude. It's the appearance of what The Dude is that makes him what he is, and weed is a strong component of that. Without the J, The Dude wouldn't be the same dude.The Dude goes back off into his exceedingly casual life and bowls with his teammates, Walter Sobchak (John Goodman) and Donny Kerabatsos (Steve Buscemi). However, not too long afterwards, The Dude receives an urgent voicemail left by Brandt requesting that The Dude come and visit, and it's not about the rug. Mr. Lebowski's wife, Bonnie, has been kidnapped for ransom. Mr. Lebowski and Brandt see The Dude as being in a unique position because they believe the men who captured Bunnie may also be the same culprits who "soiled" The Dude's rug. The Dude abides, and the rest is a crazy hilarious journey. It's like The Usual Suspects meets The Naked Gun. Jeff Bridge's performance as The Dude is one of the most recognizable in Hollywood. Him and a litany of other cast members won awards for their unique and charismatic performances. The acting is from another world, the characters are the strangest in the world, but all need each other to exist. It's almost a hallucinatory movie. The Big Lebowski is a must see for any movie fan and is sure to crack a few laughs and spark lots of curiosity. There's no better time to enjoy the turbulent journey of The Dude than now. The Big Lebowski is best served with a White Russian.

Review title: rude and crude, and i love it
Review_body: Yes, it is rude and crude. But that doesn't mean it isn't hilarious. The writing is brilliant, especially if you've seen or even read The Maltese Falcon. The directing is also great, provided by the Coen Brothers, who brought us Fargo. But the high point of the movie is definitely the acting. Jeff Bridges is the dude. It is a believable part and most importantly hilarious. He does it all, the laziness, the swearing, the acid trips. Steve Buscemi, also from Fargo, is great as Donny. His dialog, though few and far between, complements the dialog of the Dude and Walter. Which brings us to Walter, as played by John Goodman. I'm not sure who swears more, Walter or the Dude, but I would put my money on Walter. The point it is Walter who fulfills every stereotype you've heard about this movie. The rudeness, the nonsense, the lack of coherence, etc. Of course there are numerous supporting parts as well, the Big Lebowski, Jesus, etc. that only add to the film. In the end, if you love movies like Spaceballs and Bad Santa, you'll love this. If not, at least give it a chance and keep an open mind.

Have you been looking for a movie that really ties the room together? If so, The Big Lebowski is just that movie! Warning, spoiler alert!!! This movie starts out when Jeff Lebowski's, AKA the Dude (Jeff Bridges) house gets broken into by two assailants demanding money. The assailants soon learn they have the wrong Lebowski and one of them angrily urinates on the dudes' rug. The Dude, angry that his favorite rug that really tied the room together was urinated on, consults his bowling partner Walter Sobchok (John Goodman). Walter instructs the Dude that he needs to find the correct Jeff Lebowski and have him compensate him for the fouled rug. The Dude heeding Walter's instructions does just that. Upon meeting the real Jeff Lebowski, the Dude gets inadvertently involved in the kidnapping plot of Mr. Lebowski's wife Bunny (Tara Reid). Mr. Lebowski offers the Dude 25K to be the bag man and drop the ransom off to the kidnappers. The Dude then tells his bowling partner Walter, who invites himself along to perform the drop. Walter switches the ransom money with his dirty undies "the whites" and they perform the drop. The ransom money is then stolen out of the dude's trunk and he finds himself between a rock and a hard place. The kidnappers report that they did not receive the ransom so now the Dude is assailed upon by not only Mr. Lebowski but the kidnappers as well. The Dude and Walter ultimately find out that that Bunny ran away and wasn't kidnapped. They also discover that Mr. Lebowski stuffed the ransom bag with telephone books in hopes that the kidnappers would kill Bunny who was a gold digger that cheated on him. The theme of this film is? You guessed it, the Dude. The dude is an unemployed, burned out bum. He gets assaulted, he's tortured, his rug gets soiled on and his car is systematically destroyed throughout this film. He is seduced by a rich woman who uses him for her pregnancy needs. He has the chance to earn a fortune only to have it slip away. Despite all this the Dude remains very dude like! He takes on all this adversity and challenge with his calm easy- going demeanor. In the end, the dude is essentially where he began before all this strife and drama entered his life. None of this seems to bother the dude and this is why I love this film so much! The Coen brothers are amazing writers and I believe this to be their best work to date! Another film they wrote called Inside Llewn Davis had a very similar theme to the Big Lebowski. Inside Llewn Davis was about a struggling folk musician whose music partner kills himself. Llewn Davis' (Oscar Issac) record doesn't sell. He survives by sleeping on various friend's couches, one of whom he ends up impregnating his girlfriend. He takes a recording gig to be able to earn enough money to pay for his friend's girlfriend's abortion. Throughout all this adversity Llewn Davis like the Dude has a calm and easy-going demeanor and basically ends up where he began minus his record starting to take off. The use of voice-over narration and the thematic element of focusing on the character lend a lot to why this movie has taken on the cult following that it has. The voice- over narration helps to introduce us to the Dude from the beginning of this film. The stranger that narrates also points out the struggles that the Dude suffers throughout this film as well as highlight that the Dude keeps his calm. The narrator ends the movie by comforting us and letting us know that everything works out for the Dude. The thematic element of focusing on the Dude is what drives this movie. The plot is important to this film but without the Dude there would be no plot. That being said, this movies' plot is driven by the lead characters actions. The qualities that set the Dude apart from ordinary people is his ability to remain calm despite all the chaos that surrounds him. The theme of this film can be absolutely expressed in the description of the dude. If you've been looking for a good movie that really ties the room together then this is a must see! The Big Lebowski shows us that an easy-going demeanor and calmer than you are approach is the way to approach life. This movie is ensured to bring you a great film viewing experience.
Great movie to watch on movie nights with friends and family.

Review title: Or El Duderino, if you're not into the whole brevity thing.
Review_body: This movie really ties the room together.The most classic neo noir comedy caper of all time, blending old school Hollywood schlock with hippie revivalism and art house pretension funk. This is really the coolest film ever made in the modern ages. Has there ever been a more chilled out protagonist/anti-hero than the Dude? Sam Elliot narrating? Donnie, you are certainly out of your element in trying to understand how perfect this film is.

This movie came out when I was 5 and yet I was still able to find it years later and relate to the dude! Hilariously loose and laid back performance by the lead. Excellent supporting cast and an all around cult classic for sure!

This is one of the best movies ever made. After watching it for the first time I liked it but when I watched it again I just simply loved it. It's just one funny ride from beginning to the end. You can watch it as many times as you like and still find it funny. Jeff Bridges at his best with perfect John Goodman, Steve Buscemi, Julianne Moore and others. Coen brothers just gave us something rather special and you just can't go wrong with this movie. It's hard for me to understand why some people giving it only one star as it's clearly 9-10 stars movie,but as Dude said: Yeah well,you know that's just like your opinion man.

Review title: This movie made me so proud of my surname....
Review_body: ...but I never heard about any Lebowski, here in Poland. So, the winner is ...Walter;)

Watched this movie because of the 8.1 rating on imdb while it honestly deserves maximum 5 stars.
Boring to death, annoying and unlikeable characters, boring storyline with a shockingly boring ending.. forced myself and my family to finish it to try to understand the hype and the good ratings, and when you think it's done, you'll have to endure another borimg scene.
In conclusion: avoid at all costs, only wish it to someone you hate!

Review title: Unique and brilliant in its own way
Review_body: One of the coen brothers greatest movies, focusing on Jeff "the dude" Lebowski, usually mistaken for a millionaire with the same name who's wife owes money around town.This movie is so powerful, and what stood out most to me is the entrances, from scenes to characters.I also loved how none of the characters (except donnie) change very much through the movie and there's something so satisfying about almost everything going back to normal after the events. I was shocked that this film only had an 8.1 rating, it deserves much higher.

Review title: All moments of this movie - masterpiece, in some sense...
Review_body:
The best comedy of all the time.
Only a person with real talent can do film without sance so interested. And Coen's

Review title: The film with the highest rewatch factor of all time.
Review_body: It's actually kind of hard to describe this movie (and what's so great about it) to people who don't already know it and love it; as with many cult films, The Big Lebowski will either speak to you (in which case you will become a fervent follower of His Dudeness and abide by his code for the rest of your life) or, if it doesn't, the film will either leave you completely indifferent or you'll even downright hate it.I believe it's a very funny film and I'm sure it can be rightfully called a comedy, but don't expect punchlines, gags, jokes or slapstick - it's not that kind of comedy. If you want to enjoy this film, you have to meet Jeffery "The Dude" Lebowski on his terms, hang out with him and his bowling buddies and follow them at a their (perhaps somewhat leisurely) pace through this weird and unbelievable tale about nihilism, theft (of a car and, more importantly: a Creedence Clearwater Revival tape), kidnapping, abstract art, porn and - of course - bowling.The story is actually kind of simple. You see, some no-good German nihilists urinated on The Dude's rug - and this kind of aggression just won't stand against The Dude. With the help of his bowling buddies, he will do everything in his power to get someone to pay for his rug - or possibly get a new one (because that rug really tied the room together). So he embarks on this worthy quest during which he will encounter many wondrous things and fascinating people (even Jesus - who is NOT the messiah but a very naughty man).With Jeff Bridges in the leading role, the Coen brothers have found the perfect actor to incorporate one of the most iconic characters that has ever been created. But it's not just The Dude that makes this a winner; the whole film is such an inspired folly and simply inventive filmmaking at its finest (the hilarious dream sequence alone is worth the price of admission). The supporting cast is outstanding (J. Turturro, J. Goodman and S. Buscemi among many others), the song choices are perfect and the dialog is the funniest, most quotable in any comedy I've ever seen. This - for me - is without a doubt the film with the highest rewatchability factor of all time. 10 stars out of 10.

Review title: There are a lot of facets to this
Review_body:
This is a character based comedy and you really need to watch it 3-4 times to appreciate it.If you want a film that gets from A to B then you'll hate this film. If you want something to watch with the wife/gf this isn't for you. If you want something obvious or mainstream this isn't for you. If you care about plots, suspense etc. this isn't going to be your cup of tea. The people I know that like this film tend to be film connoisseurs, intellectual males, peaceful, well balanced individuals. The Coen Brothers went all out on this film. Every member of the cast made the performance of their career in this film, the cinematography is fantastic, there are so many scenes to be seen, the soundtrack is brilliant etc. etc. but what this film is all about is the dialogue. If you're a fan of films like Pulp Fiction and Fight Club where it's the excellent dialogue that brings you back then this is the ultimate film for you.I watched this by myself on a movie channel around the time of its release and a couple of years later when my younger brother told me to watch this film I couldn't remember a thing about it. I gave it another watch and half enjoyed it. My brother convinced me to watch it again so I did. This time I loved it and by the time I'd seen it 4 times it became my favourite film of all time.
After 3-4 viewings you think Jeff Bridges' 'Dude' character is the greatest movie character of all time and that he should have won an Oscar. But by the time you've seen it 6+ you realise that the greatest movie character of all time is actually John Goodman's 'Walter' and it is he who should have received an Oscar for this film.The more you watch it the more you understand the characters and find it more and more funny.You end up with one of the most quotable films and find it hard to believe that any movie fan doesn't like it.This is just my opinion man.

I love so many of the actors in this film and was really looking forward to seeing The Big Lebowski for the first time.After just watching it with such great expectations, I'm left seriously wondering what the heck is wrong with people? 
This movie was a waste of an amazing cast. This movie goes absolutely no where and is just a bunch of random, ridiculous, incoherent and implausible scenarios lazily strung together on a weak gimmick of a storyline. I really wanted to like this movie but it was just awful.

Review title: The most memorable characters of any movie I've seen
Review_body:
Whenever I try to explain The Big Lebowski to someone, I tell them that the film is 25% plot and 75% characters. While that is a cursory explanation and neglects setting as a rather large portion, I think it well portrays the priorities and attitude of the film.
 To be sure, the plot is still well crafted and exciting. It is an easily flowing story of misunderstanding, kidnapping, and deception. And it manages all three topics without a dark theme by telling it through the eyes of an unmotivated and nonchalant hippie. But the film is far more than just a plot.
 After watching it the first time, I realized that many of the scenes and dialogues could be completely omitted and the plot would still make sense. Walter bringing his wife's Pomeranian to the bowling game, as well as his constant reference to his service in the Vietnam war, and the scene where The Dude attends his landlord's dance recital, none of these contribute to the plot at all, but contribute much to character and setting development. And they are so effective that no one could really care about the extra length. They make the characters funny and memorable, and the film as such. 
 One example scene where The Dude first meets Maude, shows how the Coen brothers squeeze as much theme development as they can out of a scene. In this scene, Maude tells The Dude about Bunny and how the kidnapping is likely staged. They could have had The Dude respond to Maude's statements and conversation, as a normal scene would play out. But instead they have The Dude constantly interjecting to ask about his rug, while Maude ignores him and carries out a one-sided conversation. Doing so preserves the spacey, aloof nature of The Dude's personality, and showcases Maude's persistent and independent character, all while giving the scene a comedic mood.
 The film presses the contrasting characters of The Dude and Walter together constantly as well. Their differences - The Dude being an easy-going pacifist and Walter being an impulsive, sometimes aggressive War Vet - bring out the hilarity in both characters. They are constantly arguing, and The Dude often regrets everything that Walter brings him into (such as Walter's involvement in the hand off or Walter clubbing a stranger's sports car). But the relationship is relatable, and gives the movie a casual, familiar tone.
 Much of the hilarity also comes from how calmly The Dude handles all the events. He rarely loses his cool or questions anything. There seems to be little difference in how he handles being the courier for a ransom hand off or having his car windows smashed compared to buying cream from the grocery store. He lets viewers experience the cool and calm persona they have always wanted to be.
 The visual style of the movie is certainly memorable. Recalling it brings a specific set of colors to mind, those being a sort of orange to tan spectrum. This can be seen from The Dude's gown he always wears, to the wood, the seats, and the wall paneling of the bowling alley, to the tinted glasses always worn by Walter. This is also perpetuated by the lighting of many of the scenes, as it usually comes from warm sources like candles or sunlight when the actual surroundings are not orange in color.
 The film is a representation of a feeling or lifestyle, not merely a story. The characters live outside the movies and reside in the heads of viewers as they are some of the most memorable from a single movie in film history. It is no wonder the film has such a cult following.

Review title: What a monumental waste of time.
Review_body: I would love to have the 2 hours of my life back that I spent watching this stupid movie. Seeing the really high reviews, I decided to watch it. After about a half hour, I didn't like it, but sometimes movies take a while to get going, and the payoff might be at the end. An hour into it, it's not any better, but I figure I'm halfway through, so I might as well finish it, just in case it somehow redeems itself. That never happened, and it continued to be crap the entire time. I would say that if you watch this and don't like it after 30 minutes, just stop and go do something else, because it's not going to get any better.I've seen all these reviews from other people talking about what a great film this is, and I just don't get it. I'm reasonably intelligent, and I'm generally pretty easily entertained, but this movie was just dumb. Dumb, dumb, and dumb. Besides that, it's also stupid. I'd definitely like those two hours of my life back.

... but The Big Lebowski will, for a long time. With characters seemingly transported from a '70s hippie-exploitation B-movie, acting out a plot redolent of Raymond Chandler, only with enough slapstick to keep the Three Stooges busy for years, this movie's a bona fide hoot, whether or not you remember who Creedence was. Superb casting, line readings that shimmer, a quotable script, and a dream sequence that you'll remember every time you lace on those bowling shoes. And a soundtrack that includes Mickey Newbury's sublime "Just Dropped In (to See What Condition My Condition was In)" from 1968, sung by Kenny Rogers! I believe in nothing ... except The Big Lebowski.

Review title: You call me the Dude, or his Dudeness, or El Duderino
Review_body: The story of the Dude (Jeff Bridges) is a strange one indeed. Content to spend his days drinking white Russians and bowling with his buddies Walter (John Goodman) and Donny (Steve Buscemi), the Dude is the alpha bum and ultimate passivist. A case of mistaken identity is what forces the Dude to react (first to get reparations for his soiled rug and secondly to assist in the recovery of Bunny Lebowski) and a torrid tale of plot twists ensues. The Coen brothers are master story tellers that love to tell dark tales that focus on the internal truths of human nature. They do not give us heroes, but instead present us with realistic characters that possess questionable morals as seen in some of their other films like No Country for Old Men, Fargo and more recently The Ballad of Buster Scruggs. The Big Lebowski is no exception as every character introduced possesses some form of character flaw. Ultimately what the Coen brothers are trying to show us (Theme) is that nobody is perfect and that even a bum like the Dude can own the moral high ground over those of higher stature.The Dudes first interaction with one of these characters of higher stature occurs when he is mistaken for the other Jeffery Lebowski (David Huddleston) as one of the thugs urinates on his rug. The Dude visits Jeffery "Big Lebowski" Lebowski at his mansion to ask him to rectify the situation by paying for the soiled rug. Even though Mr. Lebowski is clearly at fault and morally obligated to make restitutions, he proceeds to deny any responsibility for the wrongful actions taken against the Dude. This theme continues when the Dude meets Jackie Treehorn (Ben Gazzara), who is the one responsible for the earlier assault. At first Jackie comes off as a reasonable man, offering to pay the Dude a finder's fee for recovering the money he is owed. We quickly find that this was just a set-up, as the Dude slowly drifts off to sleep from the drugs Jackie has mixed into his drink. On a lesser note, though Maude Lebowski's (Julianne Moore) character comes across as cold she appears to me morally sound, however she tricks the Dude into impregnating her as she does not want a father that is going to "stay in the picture". All of these characters are elevated members of society yet lack the same morality as the lowly Dude.Throughout the film, the Dudes character is challenged mostly by his friend Walter, who continues to try and manipulate the Dude's decisions. While making the drop off of the ransom money, Walter manages to botch the entire operation by throwing a "dummy" bag, and jumping out of the moving car (while driving) which subsequently wrecks into a tree while the dude is inside. However, the Dude maintains his laissez-faire attitude (except with Walter) and remains static all through the film. The reoccurring theme or motif of bowling and white Russians further solidifies the Dudes character as a devil may care "hippie" that is very much lost in time. His mind is never truly in the moment at hand, subconsciously thinking about bowling as evident in the two beautifully constructed dream sequences. The soundtrack for the film is the who's who of 60s era music, including the Dudes favorite Creedence Clearwater Revival. Deemed by many as a cult masterpiece, The Big Lebowski shows that even the humblest vagrant can be righteous if their moral compass is true.
Don't get why this is such a good movie. Just some guys bowling and one dies. Missing wife, missing rug, the end.

Review title: Well like that's your opinion man
Review_body:
It's rare that I feel obliged to write a review after seeing a movie but for this I felt I had to. This film does have a decent plot although not one you'd consider to be sensational. The main reason behind this film's popularity is it's script and characters. The performances in this film are flawless. Each actor is sensational and it honestly baffles me how there was no Oscar nods for any performances, or Oscar nods for anything at all. The script is funny although it's not one that would have you on the floor crying with laughter. The comedy is enhanced with excellent delivery and such memorability. There was a few scenes that had me desperate for air from laughing. Particularly the ending scene and the scene in which the dude nails a block of wood to the floor and put a chair against it for protection. Only to find it's an out swinging door. I would live to quote this movie with friends with lines such as obviously you're not a golfer, the dude abides, I'm the walrus or no I don't think he was close to cracking, but because of my age (I'm 16) it's rare people would understand what I'm saying and would just end up looking at me like I'm insane.
Overall just a joy to watch. Each second is a pleasure and after each time I see it I find something new in the script that I'd missed before that makes it funnier. A true great that will forever be seen as one of the greatest cult movies of all time.P. S, I also love the conversations between the trio of The dude, Donnie and Walter, The way Walter shuts down Donnie each time he speaks and the way he constantly talks about the Vietnam war and being Jewish are hilarious.

My Dad absolutely loves this film; it speaks to him on a spiritual level or something. I personally don't understand the humour, and, when I do, find it too subtle to be funny. However The Big Lebowski doesn't fit into any other category of movie, so -- what is it?For me it was a disappointment, it having been so hyped up by my Dad. For others it was an absolute triumph, if you're into that kind of film. It takes a very specific person to enjoy a movie like that, but, if you do, it will certainly be one of your favourites. I guess it's much like Marmite, a kind of love-it hate-it situation. Personally I saw the funny side of it, and the reasons for it being such a cult classic, but it just didn't fit my style.Watch Fargo instead. If you've seen it, watch it again, and then think "could the Coen brothers outdo themselves?" If the answer is no, don't spoil your own opinion of them by seeing this film. If you think they could do something more out-there or interesting, sure give The Big Lebowski a go.

If you take the time to look through some of the more negative reviews of The Big Lebowski, you'll see that a lot of people simply don't 'get' this film. Frankly, I feel sorry for them, as they are missing out on one of the funniest, smartest films ever made. The characters are outlandish and OTT and are total losers. The Dude and Walter are definitely anti-heroes, which many people (mostly Americans I'm afraid) seem to have a major problem with. However European audiences have a great love for the lazy underdog, and the Dude is typical of such bumbling idiots as Inspector Cluseau (The Pink Panther films) and Charlie Chaplin, which may explain the film's success in the UK. It has become a cult hit amongst students, and is quoted by myself and my friends frequently! The film boasts very smart writing, and is knowingly bizarre and irreverent. The dialogue is fast-paced and witty, but slightly off-kilter, to match the overall pitch of the movie. I recommend The Big Lebowski to anyone who is a fan of the Coen Brothers' work, and other films which emphasise wit over action, such as Withnail and I and Lost in Translation.
